importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the beginning of the festival of lights for over a billion people across South Asia and the diaspora.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-day Diwali festival spans from October 20 to 24, during which cultural, religious, and economic traditions are observed globally.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major festival observed by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide.
The festival is celebrated in countries such as India, Nepal, Malaysia, and Fiji, as well as in South Asian diasporas globally.
Diwali symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and justice over oppression.
It is celebrated over five days, each with unique rituals: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa, and Bhai Dooj.

Different religious traditions assign distinct meanings: for Hindus, it marks the return of Rama and Sita; for Sikhs, it commemorates the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment; for Jains, it marks the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for Buddhists, it signifies Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism.
Diwali is not just religious—it has become a cultural festival celebrated by people of all faiths and backgrounds.
Traditions include lighting oil lamps (diyas), decorating homes with rangolis, exchanging gifts, feasting, and cleaning homes.
Gambling is considered auspicious in some regions, rooted in a legend involving Shiva and Parvati.
Diwali marks the start of the new Hindu financial year, with many businesses opening new accounts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the Festival of Lights, is celebrated by over a billion people worldwide, including Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists. The festival, which falls on October 20, 2025, spans five days with distinct traditions: Dhanteras (purchase of gold and silver), Choti Diwali (Krishna’s victory over Narakasura), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (marriage and protection of villagers), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). While rooted in religious myths—such as Rama’s return from exile or the liberation of Guru Hargobind—the festival has evolved into a global cultural celebration of light, community, and new beginnings. Celebrations include lighting diyas, setting off fireworks, decorating homes with rangolis, and exchanging gifts. Diwali also marks the start of the new Hindu financial year and is observed in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and other South Asian diaspora communities.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
